pButton.Name: LUTHER
pButton.popInfo: Martin Luther (1483–1546) was a university professor and a Catholic priest who gained a new understanding about Christian doctrine and salvation.

pButton.Name: SALVATION
pButton.popInfo: Luther’s new understanding is often summarized as “Faith alone, grace alone, scripture alone.”

pButton.Name: INDULGENCES
pButton.popInfo: In 1517, Pope Leo X issued a special indulgence for the building of St. Peter’s in Rome. The head salesman was a friar named Johann Tetzel. Tetzel had a catchy slogan, “When the coin in the coffer rings, the soul from purgatory springs” and people travelled from miles around to buy his indulgences.

pButton.Name: 95 THESES
pButton.popInfo: Incensed by these and other abuses he saw in the Catholic Church, Luther wrote up a list of his concerns, called the 95 Theses, and nailed them to the door of the local church. The pope demanded that Luther recant, or take back, what he wrote.

pButton.Name: EXCOMMUNICATION
pButton.popInfo: When Luther refused to recant, he was excommunicated. The new, Protestant religion of Lutheranism was born.
